item.title: Gears Of War Co-Creator Is "Thrilled" That The Franchise Isn't Xbox Exclusive Anymore
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

This year, games that were previously Xbox-exclusive properties have been migrating to PS5, including the upcoming Gears of War remaster, Gears of War Reloaded. Just under two decades ago, the original Gears of War was one of Xbox's signature titles. Now, the co-creator of the franchise, Cliff Bleszinski, has shared his thoughts about seeing Gears of War appear on a PlayStation console.

"It doesn't feel strange," said Bleszinski during an interview with Eurogamer. "I'm thrilled that more people are going to get to experience a big part of my legacy that I worked so hard on."

Bleszinski also noted that he's interested in returning to the series as a consultant, but "crickets" has been the response from the devs. Although Bleszinski left the Gears franchise years ago, he has shared his belief that the franchise should be rebooted. Bleszinski has also revealed that he pitched an Alien game prior to Disney's purchase of Fox.

Gears of War Reloaded is the second remaster of the original game from 2006. All of the post-launch content from the game's first remaster, Gears of War: Ultimate Edition, will be included. Microsoft has sent free upgrades for Reloaded to anyone who already has Gears of War: Ultimate Edition.

Microsoft will drop Gears of War Reloaded on August 28 for Xbox Series X|S, PS5, and PC. Cross-platform play and cross-progression will be supported. It will be on Game Pass at launch. Microsoft has yet to confirm that the next game, Gears of War: E-Day, will be cross-platform when it launches in 2026 as part of Xbox's 25th anniversary.

item.title: James Gunn Aims To Reverse DC's Troubled Gaming Legacy With Long-Term Vision
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

DC games haven't had the best of times in recent years, marked by a string of missteps and canceled projects. While titles like the Batman: Arkham series found success, much of the broader DC gaming output has lacked consistency. This is something James Gunn wants to remedy as part of the 10-year plan as co-head of DC Studios.

When the rebooted DCU launched in 2023, Gunn emphasized cross-platform storytelling, noting that actors would portray their characters "across all forms of media--including video games." While there has been little public movement since then, Gunn recently confirmed that there is "slight movement on different things." That could mean we're headed toward a future where David Corenswet voices Superman in both film and other media, although Gunn didn't discuss specifics concerning Corenswet or anyone else.

“We have a couple of little DC games coming out. But we also have talked about--and in early stages of planning--some bigger things," Gunn told GamesRadar. "One thing in particular I'm excited about, but it does take time."

Both Gunn and Peter Safran are taking a proactive role in shaping DC's gaming future. Back in February, Safran gave an outlook on how they're trying to course-correct the situation and give fans must-play games again.

"James and I sit with literally the guys that run the studios…whether it's NetherRealm or whether it's Rocksteady, sit with them and talk about characters and stories that we're interested in and that they're interested in," Safran shared.

Gunn also admitted then that any major release is "at least a couple of years" away, but in the meantime, Rocksteady is said to be returning to its single-player Batman roots for its next project, as WB Games is now focusing its efforts and resources on its biggest franchises.

item.title: Razer's New Kraken Kitty Pokemon Headset Has Gengar Ears
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Razer is expanding its line of Pokemon-themed gaming gear with a new version of its Razer Kraken Kitty V2 wired gaming headset based on the fan-favorite Ghost-type Pocket Monster, Gengar. The Razer Kraken Kitty V2 Gengar Edition first launched in China a few months ago, but is now available worldwide. The headset features a special purple colorway and a headband sporting Gengar's iconic ears and headspikes, along with all the same specs, features, and device support as the standard Kraken Kitty V2 Headset--which means it works on PC and any other device with a USB Type A port. The Razer Kraken Kitty V2 Gengar Edition is available to buy now. We expect this to be a popular release, so grab the headset while you can.

Razer Kraken Kitty V2 Gengar Edition

$140

As mentioned above, Razer's new Kraken Kitty V2 Gengar Edition takes all the core features of the headset's standard model and gives it a Gengar-themed makeover with a new multi-tone purple color scheme and ornate Gengar ear pieces on top of the headband, and RGB-lit rings and Gengar decals on the outside of the earcups. The RGB lighting elements support Razer Chroma desktop app, so you can change the color and program them to react to gameplay.

Like other models of the headset, the Kraken Kitty V2 Gengar Edition uses Razer's proprietary TriForce 40mm audio drivers and HyperClear Cardioid mic. It also supports 7.1 virtual surround sound on PC (requires Windows 10 or higher). The headband and earcups use hybrid fabric and leatherette cushioning, which provides some passive noise isolation for a more immersive listen. While Windows PC users will get the most feature support, it can be connected via wired USB-A to other devices as well, including consoles, Mac computers, and more. That means Switch and Switch 2 users looking to pick up the headset ahead of Pokemon Legends: Z-A will be able to plug into their consoles while in docked mode.

The Razer Kraken Kitty V2 Gengar Edition headset is dropping just a few weeks after Razer's Pokemon Collection that launched last month. The collection includes gaming mice, mechanical keyboards, headsets, and other accessories that sport unique designs featuring Pikachu, Bulbasaur, Charmander, and Squirtle. Surprisingly, despite how fast Pokemon-themed products normally sell out, the Razer X Pokemon line is still in stock at Amazon.

More Razer X Pokemon Gaming Gear

As mentioned above, the next big Pokemon console game, Pokemon Legends: Z-A, is launching for Switch and Switch 2 on October 16, and preorders for both versions of the game are available now. Preordering at Best Buy gets you an oversized mouse pad as a physical bonus, while Walmart preorders include an exclusive enamel pin set featuring the game's starter Pokemon: Chicorita, Totodile, and Tepig. Preorders are also available at Amazon, though you won't get any bonuses, unfortunately. Along with the physical copies of the game, Nintendo is also launching a new Switch 2 bundle that includes the console and a digital copy of Pokemon Legends: Z-A that launches the same day. Check out our Pokemon Legends: Z-A preorder guide for more information.

item.title: Capcom Gears Up For Resident Evil 30th-Anniversary Celebration With New Website
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Apologies to fans of the series who have been playing it since the very first game, but next year, Resident Evil turns 30. The first game came out all the way back in 1996, on March 22 to be precise, with many games having been released in the meantime. There's obviously a new game releasing next year, Resident Evil Requiem, but it seems that aside from putting out a new entry, Capcom is also planning … something for the series' 30th anniversary. A new anniversary website is now available for you to peruse, only right now there's not much to look at.

At the top of the site is a beautiful piece of art showcasing the game's numerous protagonists, like Leon Kennedy, Claire and Chris Redfield, Jill Valentine, Ada Wong, and Resident Evil Requiem's main character Grace Ashcroft.

Apart from that, there's what appears to be a 30th-anniversary logo next to some text that simply reads, "2026 marks the 30th anniversary of the Resident Evil series!" There's also a drawing of a raccoon wearing sunglasses also commemorating the 30th anniversary, in front of a spinning disc that says, "coming soon … " on it.

Given that Resident Evil Requiem is due out February 27 next year, you probably shouldn't expect a big new game announcement, but some appropriately themed merchandise does seem likely at the very least. Given that the anniversary is only about seven months away, it probably won't be too long until we find out what Capcom has planned.
